bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 20, 1941

div1.p: Kean details his involvement in the National Memorial to Thomas Jefferson. Kean also discusses the publication of Truby's manuscript, his meeting with Carlos E. Finlay, and his understanding that Reed visited Carlos J. Finlay before any efforts were made to infect mosquitoes.

My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
What a human dynamo you are and
what a glutton for work! Working until 3 or 4 a.m.
when you are a sick man is very good cause for
Mrs Hench's “anxious anger” and Mrs. Kean says
to tell you that her sympathies are entirely with
Mrs. H. Take a lesson from your friend who select-
ed your hospitable home as a good place to
have a coronary occlusion and stop driving
when your sleep time comes. I who really am
loafing along now, have just got through with
a pleasant job (or I think I have) which has occu-
pied much of my time for the past year.
I am on a committee of the Commission listed above
which has been mulling over the question of the inscrip-
tions for the 4 great panels in the beautiful temple
for the National Memorial to Thomas Jefferson just
now approaching completion. Now that would seem
2.
to be a simple matter, but T. J. was interested in & had a
hand in so many things and wrote so much that it
is difficult to decide what are preeminent enough to
find a place in these panels. Only his own words are to
be used and as the bronze letters will be 4″ high
the architect only allows about 50 words for each
panel. So to arrive at a consensus of opinion
among 12 men from different parts of the country
and different shades of political opinions and more
than half of them lawyers has been some job. And
it has been arrived at largely by correspondence.
T. J. believed from his youth that all men should be
free even tho. black men though none of his prominent cotemporaries were
thought so, or if they did, were un-willing to have their
belief put into practice. So when he proposed before
(1) the Revolution to prohibit the slave trade in Va. in 1774 it was
(2) defeated. He got this though the Va. Legislature in 1778.
(3) He wrote into the Declaration of Independence a denuncia-
tion of the King for supporting the slave trade. It was cut
out when Congress voted on the Declaration.
(4) He proposed in the Continental Congress in 1783 that
slavery be prohibited in the new territory west of
the Alleghanies. This was lost by one vote so far as
Allebama, Missippippi Tenesessee and Kentucky
were concerned. But he had the matter referred
to a committee to handle for the North-West
Territory, north of the Ohio, which Virginia gave to the
(5) Union and it was adopted (Forbidding Slavery) in 1787.
J. R. K. to P. H. S. 10/21/41.
3
Abraham Lincoln in his debate with Douglas
at Columbus, O. in 1859 told his audience that
it was due to “This same Mr. Jefferson” that they
were living in free states. When the Constituition
was adopted in 1788 T. J. was in France as our
minister, so he did not get a chance to defeat
the carefully hidden joker in Art. I. Section 9, of that
document which prohibited Congress from interfer-
ing with the slave trade for 20 years. But when that
(6) time expired T. J. was President and he sent an
urgent message to Congress asking for the suppres-
sion of “ This execrable commerce”. This was promptly
done and the next year he retired from political
life leaving to a future President fifty years later to
take up the fight against African Slavery.

Now would you imagine that when I proposed
that one of the panels should state T.J.S attitude
towards slavery, I did not get at first a single
vote in favor of it! But I have been very tena-
cious and persistant and have finally won out.
I will send you the four panels when they are
published. They are not just as I would have them
but in a matter like this one cannot have every thing
his own way.

Now why should I take up my whole letter with this
matter? in which probably you are not at all interested
J.R.K. to P.S.H. 10/21/41.
AC
K
4
altho you have the historical much sense much more
developed than most men. I am so much occupied
with it that when I got started I could not stop.
Gen. Ireland came in just after I started
to write this letter. He said he had a letter
from you and I Told him I could go him one
better. I had two from you yesterday in
the same mail, one from Rochester and the
other from New Orleans. We talked over
your suggestion, with which Dr. Hewitt agrees,
that Truby should first offer his memoir
to a publisher before asking the S.G. to print
it at Carlisle. We agree that it would be
better if Truby could be secured against being
involved in the expense of publication. He
should not be asked to under write it at all.
As Gen. Ireland said you probably did not
appreciate how close to the wind a retired
officer has to sail to avoid the rocks. Also
the S.G. can give it a some what restricted but
very interested circulation, by a free distribu-
tion to the Army Libraries and the Officers
of his Corps. He printed printed Col. L.C. Dun-
cau's fine work “Medical Officers in the American
Revolution” at Carlisle in this way, a bound volume of 414
pages in 1931. Duncans” Medical Department of the
U. S. Army in the Civil War” was printed by me
as a series of articles in the Military Surgeon
in 1912, & 1913 and the S. G. bought them, reprinted
5
and bound in volumes of 355 pages of excellent
stuff. I am sorry to note that, on referring to this
volume to see the no. of pages, they are not remem-
bered. I do not suppose that these books could
be now obtained, unless at a second hand book
dealers. But the commercial publishers
do not keep their type and the unsold books
long either. We think that the matter of publi-
cation is for Truby to decide but he should be
warned again assuming any of the risks
of publication. That is the publisher's gamble.

What a nice discriminating note of review that
of Dr. Hewitt was. I had a call sunday from
Dr. Carlos E. Finlay of Havana. He came up to
the meeting of the Public Health Association at
Atlantic City. He gets much like the old man
in appearance, voice and manner as he gets
older (he is 71 now) He has the same little hesita-
tion in his speech and articulates as if he had hot
mush in his month. He has also his fathers kindliness
of manner. He assures to be pleased with the
Conquerors of Yellow Fever but said that his prefer-
ence was for the smaller group which Cornwell
had in mind when he came to Cuba.

I will make you up a bundle of old retained papers
& send them by express, which is much cheaper
than 1stclass mail when it gets to half a pound
or more. I take it that you are glad to get
autographs of men of mark - as Finlay, Gorgas & Guiteras
AC
K
6
I am leaving it to you to do the throwing away
as you suggest, but how with all the things
you have in hand you will find time to look
at them I do not see.

From your interesting note from N.D. I understand
that you think or Dr. Matas thinks Agramonte proposed the visit to
Dr. Finlay after the first series of experiments
at the Columbia Bks Hospital failed, but I have
always understood that Reed went to see Finlay
before any efforts were made to infect mosqui-
toes. Reed states definitely that the experiments
were made with mosquitos hatched from the ova
which Dr. Finlay gave him. He left about Aug 1st
and the first series of experiments was began
by Lazear or Aug. 11th. I am returning your
letter so you can see what I am talking
about. I could not make out the word
that I have drawn my pencil around.
This has been a much interrupted letter
and please excuse the excustion about
T.J. and slavery if it does not interest you
I hope you were well by the time you return-
ed home and had caught up on sleep.
I find the Proceedings of the Mayo Staff meetings
very interesting.
